data.title: Mac OS X Yosemite starting atom with correct path (solution?)
data.body:
When I put Atom in my Apple Dock and clicked on the icon Atom started successfully but couldn't find needed programs in my PATH. I've spent sometime finding a possible solution.
1. Instead of having a binary in the Atom.app/Contents/MacOS use your script Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/atom.sh.
2. The script needs 2 changes:
   - change for the new location of the binary
   - change the first line of the script from:
     #!/usr/bin/env bash
     to:
     #!/usr/bin/env bash -l

This seems to start Atom from a bash shell that runs the ~/.profile script first allowing all of the environment variables to get set and made visible to Atom.

OS X still does not have shared global environment variables. But it does help establish the login environment variables for atom including PATH.

I've made a new application just for your script as my current work around.

Thanks,
Mark Zander
tarzander@hotmail.com

data.title: Cmd+t menu allows opening new file in same tab by using shift+enter or shift+click.
data.body: Discussed over on https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/145, but giving it a little more light here.

data.title: Screenshot on atom.io homepage shows old theme
data.body: I know this is minor in the scheme of things, but I noticed the homepage for https://atom.io still has the Atom Dark theme, not the One Dark UI theme as the screenshot.

data.title: Atom API reference - Include class name in title
data.body:
Would be nice if the title for the API reference pages gave some context to the class it's referencing. The following is a screenshot of the tabs I see in Firefox (Safari gives even less context because the icon is missing). All of them just say "Atom".

![screen shot 2015-05-31 at 5 29 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2596124/7904012/f1380a46-07ba-11e5-8fd2-7e8c0f82ac57.png)

The left tab has the API reference for Color, the middle for CommandRegistry, and the right for TextBuffer, but it's unclear without selecting them which one's which. 

Propose something along the lines of "Atom - TextBuffer API" or even just "Atom - TextBuffer" for clarity. 

/cc @thedaniel :memo:

data.title: Support copy with Keyboard shortcut when the Preview Window is focused
data.body:
When we open the Preview Window, say when editing a `.md` file, let us press `Ctrl+C` to copy the selected text. Currently that only works from the context menu.

Please note that copying from a normal paragraph works, BUT if you select the text from a `Fenced code block` it wont work. I'm using Atom 0.204.0.

data.title: Invalid Bracket Matching
data.body:
Hello :smile:,

So I've been working with Atom quite a while now and noticed a bug when Atom matches curly brackets. The main issue here is that brackets in special scopes/context should be ignored like in comments or regex objects (eg. Javascript).

![invalidbm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5961244/7902279/de8d894e-07b4-11e5-8c9f-131173e037ef.png)

Atom 0.204.0 on Windows 7 x64.

But atom got installed! I can launch it like any other app from GUI. I use Ubuntu 14.04.

Please help!

```
$ atom
$ nohup: failed to run command ‘/tmp/atom-build/Atom/atom’: No such file or directory

```

data.title: Opening 'Settings' - 'Packages' takes too long time
data.body: Even if I want to find specific package, first it lays out all packages.

data.title: Atom Editor Memory Leak... 202 didn't decrease memory usage, it increase it by 4x.
data.body:
The recent 202 release increase the memory usage of Atom on my system with sparse editing by 4x+ in that I used to max out at about 1gb over a few days of editing files (I don't normally close my editor.) However, with the recent 202 release my memory usage creeped up to over 4gb plus, for some reason it seems to be swap thrashing (a problem we solved by simply denying swap access to Atom.) 

On a side/potentially-related note, I also get tons of messages like this in my console now:

```
events.js:232 (node) warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 data listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit.events.js:232 addListener
events.js:236 console.trace()events.js:236 addListener
events.js:232 (node) warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 data listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit.
events.js:236 console.trace()events.js:236 addListener
```

data.title: Auto update didn't work (twice) release notes is stuck at 0.196.0
data.body:
I installed 0.201 weeks ago, the auto update didn't work I had to use installer. Today I noticed auto updating once again didn't work. I ran uninstaller, and installed a new one.

Now the Help menu says my version is 0.204.0 but the _release notes_ are stuck at 0.196.0. Also showing "Restart and update" button, yet my version is just downloaded.

I think I have to delete `.atom`, uninstall the whole thing. Somehow some parts, like release notes are stuck in the past.

Using Windows 8.1, 64 bit.

data.title: Indentation glitch in certain scopes but not others.
data.body:
Hey there! I've just noticed a somewhat strange glitch in how Atom responds to <kbd>Tab</kbd> in certain scopes---in particular Markdown, but I haven't cycled through them all yet. Setting the tab length to four spaces, either in `.gfm.source` or globally, causes Atom to insert four spaces but visually snap the cursor back to the middle of the tabstop, roughly two spaces in. From there, typing causes the cursor to jump back and insert text at the expected position about half of the time, and about half the time to drop text right where it appears to be, with two spaces before the insertion and two spaces trailing it. This also happens when I type four spaces the old-fashioned way.

I dropped a quick screencast demonstrating the hiccup at https://cloudup.com/cUq4wn72BsS. It was recorded with a brand-new, untampered-with Atom setup: I reinstalled the binary to be safe, and moved my `~/.atom` folder out of `$HOME`. The same behavior occurred, both without any third-party packages present and in safe mode.

So far I can attest that this _doesn't_ happen in plain-text mode, in Python, or with the scopes created by the `language-latex` package, but I can't generalize beyond that yet.

Please let me know if I can provide any more or any better information about the problem! And thanks in advance for your help.

data.title: Atom is being treated as malware by antivirus programs on Windows.
data.body:
I had this issue on several machines running Windows 8.1 x64. `atom.exe` is flagged due to suspicious activities.

The antivirus programs tried:
- Avast
- Bitdefender

data.title: Added , how to create a launcher icon in new build
data.body: This source build doesn't create any launcher icon . So we have to manually add it .

data.title: Optimize marker observation
data.body:
Depends on new `text-buffer` features. See atom/text-buffer#66.

This is one of several optimizations aimed at addressing Atom's slowness when an editor has a lot  of markers (e.g. find-and-replace results, spell-check highlights).
#### Problem

Currently, each decorated marker in the editor is individually observed by the `TextEditorPresenter` using `Marker::onDidChange`. Even though the presenter doesn't do much work for markers that are off-screen, just emitting all these change events becomes expensive when there are 10,000+ markers. The main cost is computing each marker's screen coordinates based on the underlying buffer coordinates.

This is a flame graph taken while inserting a newline into a file 2800 line file with 17000 search results. It took **1.5 seconds**. The region between the red arrows is emitting marker change events.

![screen shot 2015-06-04 at 10 50 45 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/7990786/27838374-0aa8-11e5-8c6e-e64d0377c29a.png)
#### Solution

~~We've added a new API on `TextEditor` called `::observeMarkers()`, which allows you to observe any marker changes within a particular region of the editor.~~ The presenter now simply recomputes decoration states whenever any markers update. It determines that markers have updated using the text-buffer's `::onDidUpdateMarkers` method. This means that most markers are not observed, so they can avoid observing changes to their underlying `text-buffer` marker, preventing unnecessary screen-coordinate translations.

The same operation as performed above now takes **170 ms**. Still not fast, but we've removed a bottleneck.

data.title: Introduce atom.directory-searcher service v0.1.0.
data.body:
The contract for a provider for the `atom.directory-searcher` service
is defined by the spec of the `DefaultDirectorySearcher`.

This modifies `Workspace::scan()` to use the appropriate `DirectorySearcher`
for each member of `atom.project.getDirectories()` when scanning the workspace
for files that match the specified regex.

data.title: Don't load packages with deprecations
data.body:
Adds a list of package name and versions not to load since they contain deprecations and will break once the deprecated Atom APIs are removed.

Refs #6867

data.title: Constrain length of invisible character strings in settings
data.body: We don't currently support invisible character strings that exceed a single character. Previously, rendering went haywire when users specified strings that were longer. This PR disallows that.

data.title: Windows Alt Key Code Combinations for Special Characters Not Possible
data.body:
On Windows systems, you can hold the Alt key and type a number combination on the number pad to insert special characters. For example, I can insert an m-dash (—) by holding Alt and typing 0151.

This works fine in most text editors, including Sublime Text; however, in Atom, the Alt key + a number results in switching to a different tab.

data.title: Restoring session doesn't work for Term2 tab
data.body:
1. Install https://github.com/webBoxio/atom-term2
2. Open Term2 tab (CTRL+SHIFT+T)
3. Close Atom
4. Open Atom without arguments

Excepted behavior: All tabs are restored.

Current behavior: A tab with terminal doesn't appear.

I'm not sure if it's Atom's bug or Term2's bug.

data.title: Setting toggle for default atom command line behavior
data.body:
Atom's default `atom` command behavior isn't going well with my workflow. From the discussions I've seen, a lot of people want the old behavior and some people enjoy the new behavior, making it the perfect candidate for a toggle setting. The behavior can be worked around by hacking a bash script, but I don't think that's a good user experience for a common workflow.

Before the implementation I'd like to get some input on where the setting should live. My thought is the setting doesn't have a good place on the GUI settings page, so maybe just a field in the config file will work for now.
